Article Title: A saint goes with his gut instinct
Article Text:
Thirukkural

with the Times explores real-world lessons from the classic Tamil text ‚ÄòThirukkural‚Äô. Written by Tamil poet and philosopher Thiruvalluvar, the Kural consists of 1,330 short couplets of seven words each. This text is divided into three books with teachings on virtue, wealth, and love and is considered one of the great works ever on ethics and morality. The Kural has influenced scholars and leaders across social, political, and philosophical spheres.

Motivational speaker, author and diversity champion Bharathi Bhaskar explores the masterpiece.

Kural 946:

atham, piththam

abam

‚ÄúI had a gut feeling‚Äù.

Audio Production:

Sahil Gupta

Voice your thoughts! Email us at

When I was young, my aunt often took me to the discourses of Krubananda Variyaar. I remember sitting in crowded halls, listening to him unwrap profound truths with humour.In one, he told the story of a saint who lived on food grown in his garden, cooked his own meals and wanted for nothing. The king, his disciple, kept inviting him to the palace. One day, the saint agreed. A lavish dinner was served, and finally, payasam arrived in a golden cup studded with diamonds.The next day, the palace found the cup missing. The minister went to the saint‚Äôs ashram to ask about it, but before he could speak, the saint confessed. ‚ÄúI was going to return it today,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI kept wondering how such a desire entered my mind. Perhaps when I ate palace food, the thoughts and desires of everyone there seeped into me. Desire made me steal.‚Äù Variyaar Swami paused and concluded, ‚ÄúYou are what you eat.‚ÄùOnly years later did I fully understand it.Our gut is home to trillions of microorganisms that form a richness as biodiverse as the Amazon rainforest. Good bacteria digest food, produce hormones, control blood sugar and influence our moods. A doctor once told me that 90% of cells are bacterial; only 10% are human. In many ways, we are more microbe than man.No wonder the gut is called the second brain.Thiruvalluvar‚Äôs chapter on ‚ÄòMedicine‚Äô throws us into a sea of surprise. It does not speak of any branch of practices or procedures. Six out of 10 couplets in this chapter talk about gut health and the need for moderation in eating . Among them,Izhivarindhu UnbaanKann InbanPol NirkkumKazhiperu IrayaanKann Noai.As pleasure dwells with a moderate eater,So is disease with a voracious glutton.He was perhaps aware that gut health is the key to all health.Ilya Mechnikov, the Russian scientist of the early 1900s, accidentally opened the world‚Äôs eyes to gut microbes. To prove the body houses vast bacterial populations, he drank a broth of bacteria. He remained fine; his student too. But a third colleague nearly died. That was when Mechnikov realised each person carries a unique microbial world. What nourishes one may endanger another. Balance is the key.Mechnikov would have turned in his grave had he known about the invention of antibiotics. He would have been distressed to see antibiotics destroying good bacteria along with the harmful ones.Indian medical systems, interestingly, did not see microbes as enemies or as causes of illness. They focused on balancing vand. Here again, balance is the key.Modern research now says the gut operates almost independently. The digestive tract contains more than 100 million neurons. Serotonin, our natural antidepressant, is mainly produced in the gut. And that is why we sayOur emotional signals often start in the gut long before they reach the mind.When this delicate system is disrupted through overeating, irregular meals, or processed foods, the results are immediate. Public health experts call obesity the silent second pandemic. Late-night biryani shops, round-the-clock food delivery, and eating at all hours have become routine. And through it all, our gut silently loses its balance.Thiruvalluvar‚Äôs rule remains the best remedy: eat what you can digest, and what truly agrees with your system.Science affirms it.Experience repeats it.And our own gut whispers it, quietly, persistently reminding us that well-being beginswith what we choose to place inside.

Written by Tamil poet and philosopher Thiruvalluvar, the Kural is considered one of the great works ever on ethics and morality. The Kural has influenced scholars and leaders across social, political and philosophical spheres.

Congress high command‚Äôs decision on Karnataka leadership change is likely only after January.

The delay can be linked to CM Siddaramaiah‚Äôs personal goal of staying in office until 6 January 2026.

Remaining in office till that date would allow Siddaramaiah to match D Devaraj Urs‚Äô record as Karnataka‚Äôs longest-serving CM.

Siddaramaiah sees completing a full five-year term as part of his political legacy and believes this is his last term.

Analysts say Siddaramaiah‚Äôs Ahinda base and political journey mirror that of Urs, who championed backward-class empowerment.

BENGALURU: The tussle for Karnataka‚Äôs chief ministerial post has intensified, with camps supporting chief minister Siddaramaiah and his deputy DK Shivakumar (DKS) stepping up pressure. Both leaders insist the final decision rests with the Congress high command, even as political signalling intensifies on the ground.Amid political drama both leaders were seen together on stage in an event on Friday.A day earlier, Siddaramaiah asserted that he would complete his full five-year term as CM, while Shivakumar publicly dismissed all speculation of a leadership change, saying he is ‚Äúnot in a hurry‚Äù and has had no discussions with senior Congress leaders on the CM post.During his visit to Mumbai, DKS clarified that he met no national leaders.‚ÄúI came only for a family function. There was no meeting. If a meeting has to happen, it will be in Bengaluru or Delhi,‚Äù he said.Speculation around a mid-term power shift continues to be fueled by the 2023 'power-sharing arrangement', frequently referenced in political circles.Spiritual leader Dr Nanjavadhutha Mahaswamiji, pontiff of the Sri Guru Gundla Brahmeshwara Mahasamsthana, said, "We had expected Siddaramaiah to become the CM in the first term. Considering his age, we thought he would be given the opportunity. The high command had promised to make him CM for at least 2.5 years. All sections of society are supporting Shivakumar. Let's first resolve the issue there and give Shivakumar an opportunity"Karnataka BJP President BY Vijayendra took a dig at Congress, saying it would not be surprising if Karnataka Congress splits into two factions.While Vijayendra stated that the BJP has nothing to do with the "internal bickering" within the ruling Congress, he added, the state administration is being affected.Former CM and BJP leader Jagdish Shettar says Karnataka's financial situation is already critical and the ongoing power tussle over the CM post is going to affect it adversely.AICC president Mallikarjun Kharge‚Äôs son, Priyank Kharge, met Shivakumar at his Bengaluru residence on Friday morning, adding curiosity to the already charged atmosphere. Priyank maintained that the high command will intervene only when necessary, and urged an end to needless speculation.‚ÄúCongress was, is, and will remain united. We walk the talk,‚Äù he said.Several Vokkaliga community organisations have come out openly in support of Shivakumar, with plans to write to the Congress leadership urging that he be made the CM.MLA HC Balakrishna threw his weight behind DKS, stating that the high command must step in and take a decision soon. He expressed hope that Shivakumar would eventually take oath as Chief Minister.Congress MLC and Siddaramaiah‚Äôs son, Yathindra, reiterated his support for the current CM, saying he is unaware of any power-sharing pact between his father and DKS.Congress chief Mallikarjun Kharge clarified that a leadership decision will be made after consultations involving central leaders, Siddaramaiah, and Shivakumar. He underscored the need for deliberation before any move is made.

Article Title: Siddaramaiah vs Shivakumar in Karnataka: Did Congress high command fail to act on time, yet again?
Article Text:
'All 140 MLAs Are Mine': DK Shivakumar Amid Karnataka CM Speculation; Siddaramaiah Responds

NEW DELHI: The Congress would have a strong feeling of deja vu about the turn of events in Karnataka. The grand-old-party stares at a political crisis in the state that threatens the very stability of its government. Ironically, while the crisis is in Karnataka, on test is the Congress high command - which has proved to be a bad crisis manager in recent times.The open power tussle between chief minister Siddaramaiah and deputy chief minister D K Shivakumar has reached a point of no return, forcing the top leadership into a huddle. Ironically, the seeds of the current crisis were sown two-and-a-half years back - when both the regional stalwarts had staked claim to the CM post - following the party's emphatic victory over the BJP in the 2023 assembly elections. So the big question is: Has the top Congress leadership failed to act in time, yet again?We have seen similar leadership tussles play out in two states - Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan - where the factionalism between state Congress leaders played a key role in the party eventually losing power. The common thread in all three states has been the Congress leadership's reluctance to act decisively in the fight between the party's old guard and the younger leaders.In Madhya Pradesh, when Jyotiraditya Scindia wanted to step into the leadership role, Congress backed veteran heavyweights Kamal Nath and Digvijaya Singh . This eventually saw the Scindia Junior quitting the party and joining the BJP. Scindia's revolt brought down the Congress government and in the next assembly elections, Kamal Nath and Digivijay Singh failed miserably to counter the BJP.Today, the Congress in Madhya Pradesh is in doldrums while Scindia is a Union minister.In Rajasthan, when Sachin Pilot, who as state president had led the Congress to emphatic victory in 2018, sought the chief minister's chair, the party again backed state veteran Ashok Gehlot. Gehlot, who had led the party to defeat in 2013, became the chief minister again and Sachin Pilot and his supporters were left disappointed. When Sachin stepped up his campaign for the top job, Gehlot used his full might to crush the rebellion. Pilot, who camped at a resort with his supporters, was eventually convinced by the Gandhi family to stay with the party. While the party high command bet big on Gehlot, he could not win the state in 2024.Now, we see a similar script play out in Karnataka. Siddramaiah, who was made the chief minister in 2013, led the party to defeat in 2018. DK Shivakumar, as the state Congress president, played a key role in the party's victory in 2023. But once again, senior leader Siddaramaiah staked claim to the top post and the party eventually went with him. DKS then remained defiant for almost a week before eventually relenting. DKS now claims that there was a secret deal in the know of five-six people about rotating the post of chief minister and wants the Congress high command to ensure that he gets his due. But the Congress high command, as usual, allowed the crisis to blow out of hand. And now, when the factionalism is out in the open, it is trying to broker a truce.The last-minute crisis management may save the Congress government in Karnataka for now, but the open power tussle has the potential to damage the party's image and perhaps also its electoral prospects. The Congress had managed a historic victory against the BJP in 2023. Instead of consolidating its gains, the party finds itself managing the power play between its state leadership. But then, this is how the Congress high command has worked in recent years. The Congress high command needed to anticipate this crisis in Karnataka and should have worked to find a balance between Siddaramaiah, who is past his prime, and DKS - who is the strongest contender to lead the party forward. Perhaps the Congress leadership needs to be reminded about an old adage: A stitch in time saves nine.It will be interesting to see how the Congress high command wriggles out of this crisis and how much this impacts the party's prospects in the 2028 assembly elections. Is the grand old party on the verge of losing yet another state?
Article Summary: The open power tussle between chief minister Siddaramaiah and deputy chief minister D K Shivakumar has reached a point of no return. We have seen similar leadership tussles play out in two states - Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan. The common thread in all three states has been the Congress leadership's reluctance to act decisively in the fight between the party's old guard and the younger leaders.

became the latest high-profile athlete toafter $185,000 worth of luxury watches and jewelry vanished from his room at The Dominick Hotel in Manhattan‚Äôs SoHo district. The robbery unfolded on September 5, 2025, turning what should have been a routine offseason stay into a headline-making ordeal. Hart had dropped off his duffle bag containing a prized watch case around 12:30 p.m., only to return an hour later and find it missing.The incident has since stirred widespread conversation, not only because of the staggering value of the stolen items but also due to the brazenness of the midday heist at a high-end hotel known for celebrity clientele and tight security. As the story circulated, speculation mounted regarding how such a theft could occur inside a property that prides itself on exclusivity and safety.Investigators confirmed that Josh Hart‚Äôs bag contained three luxury watches and a bracelet, although the specific brands - whether Rolex, Audemars Piguet, or otherwise - have not been revealed. What is clear is that the case disappeared from his room in broad daylight shortly after Hart checked in.The Knicks guard had recently signed an $81 million contract and was staying downtown despite maintaining a residence in Westchester, as he was set to attend an event in New York City on September 6.With no arrests or suspects named as of late November, police have not yet determined whether the theft was the work of hotel staff, other guests, or a calculated crew familiar with the area. The lack of leads has only intensified public curiosity about the circumstances surrounding the crime.Josh Hart isn‚Äôt merely a role player; he‚Äôs become one of New York‚Äôs most dependable contributors. Last season, he broke the franchise record for single-season triple-doubles, and under new head coach Mike Brown he has continued averaging 10.4 points and 7.1 rebounds. Off the court, Hart is known for his passion for high-end fashion and watches, an interest shared by many NBA stars. Similar thefts involving Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Karl-Anthony Towns have only fueled debates about whether professional athletes should travel with expensive jewelry.Hart also remains a beloved Villanova alum, part of the 2016 NCAA championship team with Jalen Brunson and Mikal Bridges - now his Knicks teammates - adding even more public attention to his situation.Also read: Oklahoma junior college basketball player, Ethan Dietz, tragically passes away after suffering fatal in-game injury The NYPD continues to investigate but has yet to uncover meaningful leads. The case mirrors a growing pattern of athlete-targeted thefts, with even celebrities like Keanu Reeves having watches recovered through federal investigations. For Hart, the loss is significant, but those familiar with his relentless playing style expect him to bounce back quickly as the Knicks chase NBA Cup success against the Bucks. Whether the stolen pieces ever reappear, however, remains an open question as the case moves forward.
Article Summary: New York Knicks guard Josh Hart was robbed of $185,000 worth of luxury watches and jewelry at a Manhattan hotel.
